questiontext.text: In a negative auto-regulation circuit, what happens when you increase the maximum transcription rate while keeping other parameters constant?

generalfeedback.text: The maximum transcription rate affects both the response time and steady state level in negative auto-regulation. A higher transcription rate leads to faster accumulation of the protein, which then more quickly reaches the threshold needed for auto-repression. The steady state also increases because the stronger production can maintain a higher concentration even with negative feedback.

answer.text: Response time increases but steady state remains the same

feedback.text: Incorrect. A higher transcription rate actually decreases response time due to faster protein accumulation. The steady state also changes due to the shifted balance between production and repression.

answer.text: Response time and steady state both decrease

feedback.text: Incorrect. While response time does decrease, the steady state actually increases with higher transcription rate as the system can maintain a higher concentration despite negative feedback.

answer.text: Response time decreases and steady state increases

feedback.text: Correct! Higher transcription rate leads to faster protein accumulation (decreased response time) and can maintain a higher steady state level despite negative feedback.

answer.text: Only steady state increases, response time unchanged

feedback.text: Incorrect. Both response time and steady state are affected. The faster production rate leads to quicker approach to steady state.

answer.text: Neither response time nor steady state changes

feedback.text: Incorrect. Both response time and steady state are affected by changes in transcription rate in a negative auto-regulation circuit.

name.text: Q2 NAR vs Simple Regulation Response Time

questiontext.text: When comparing the response times of simple regulation and negative auto-regulation:

generalfeedback.text: Negative auto-regulation is a speed-up mechanism in gene circuits. The key to this behavior is that when the maximum transcription rate is high, the initial production is very fast, and then the negative feedback kicks in to prevent overshooting. This makes it faster than simple regulation which approaches steady state more gradually.

feedback.text: Incorrect. Negative auto-regulation is actually designed to speed up response times compared to simple regulation.

answer.text: Both systems have identical response times

feedback.text: Incorrect. The systems have fundamentally different dynamics due to the presence of feedback in the auto-regulated system.

answer.text: Negative auto-regulation reaches steady state faster with higher maximum transcription rate

feedback.text: Correct! The high initial production rate combined with negative feedback creates a faster approach to steady state compared to simple regulation.

answer.text: Response time is independent of regulation type

feedback.text: Incorrect. The type of regulation significantly affects response time dynamics.

answer.text: Simple regulation has more predictable response times

feedback.text: Incorrect. Both systems have predictable response times, but negative auto-regulation is consistently faster.
